utterances: (Soundbite of music)
This is an election special from NPR News, the day after.
I'm Neal Conan in Washington.
Senator John McCain made what may have been one of the most difficult speeches of his life last night.
Speaking in Phoenix, he conceded defeat to his Democratic rival and commended him on his historic victory.
In a contest as this long and difficult as this campaign has been, his success alone commands my respect for his ability and perseverance.

But that he managed to do so by inspiring the hopes of so many millions of Americans who had once wrongly believed that they had little at stake or little influence in the election of an American president is something I deeply admire and commend him for achieving.
Republican presidential candidate, John McCain, in Phoenix last night.
Today, we're looking at what happened yesterday in the campaign for president and in Congress.
NPR political editor, Ken Rudin, is with us.
We want to hear from you.
If this is a new beginning, what begins and what ends?
We have split lines today.
We are asking Obama backers to call 800-344-3864.
McCain supporters, 800-344-3893.
And joining us now is Andrew Kohut, director of the Pew Research Center for the People and the Press.
He's with us here in studio 3-A.
A late night for you, too, Andy.
We thank you very much for coming in today.
Happy to be here.
And what John McCain just said in that tape cut, he spoke to Barack Obama's success in expanding the electorate.
A lot of people wondered how big was the black turnout going to be, how big was the youth turnout going to be.
Well, the black turnout went from - it was 11 percent of the electorate four years ago.
This time, it was 13 percent.
That's about a 20 percent boost.
That's very substantial.
19 percent of African-Americans were first-time voters, only eight percent of whites were first-time voters.
Much - there's a lot going on with African-Americans and they voted heavily - much more heavily for Obama than they did for Kerry.
The youth vote is a bit of a puzzle.
(Soundbite of laughter)
We find about the same percentage of young voters.
I think it was 17 percent this time as four years ago.
But of course, there was increased youth turnout because we had historically high levels of turnout, but they were across the board.

We really can't come to the conclusion unless there's a problem with this exit poll that young people turned out - the turnout was disproportionately higher than elsewhere or the rate of change was disproportionately greater.
And that is somewhat of a surprise.
Given all the interest that we saw, particularly in the primaries.
Right.
Well - and what they did do is they voted so heavily for Barack Obama.
They are real factor in his.
There are factor - two things - in his election and a factor in the new distribution of the electorate.
Four years ago, the electorate divided about evenly, Republican versus Democrat.
In this election, 32 percent of the voters, according to the exit polls thought of themselves as Republicans dropped of five, 40 percent Democrats.
A big advantage for the Democrats in part because this generation, this age cohort of young people, 18 to 30, maybe a little bit more, they're very Democratic.
And a lot of Republicans worry that they have lost a generation and the other also worry about Latinos, the other big ethnic group in this country, bigger ethnic group than African-Americans.
Well, they certainly lost the Latinos.
We saw them lose them in 2006 and Latinos voted more Democratic, 15 percentage points more Democratic this time relative to four years ago.
And the Latino vote and the African-American vote was so heavily Barack - supportive of Barack Obama.
It overcame the fact that whites still on balance voted for John McCain.
Ken, we're getting a lot of emails asking what happens to replace the two senators who won yesterday, but will get new jobs - Joe Biden in Delaware and Barack Obama in Illinois.
Both states will stay - both Senate seats will stay Democratic.
The governor of Illinois is Rod Blagojevich.
I'll say that one time, fast.
He's a Democrat and there is tremendous pressure on him to name an African-American Barack Obama being the only black in the Senate.
Jesse Jackson, Jr., the congressman, certainly is interested in the seat.
He doesn't have the greatest relationship with Blagojevich.
A possible name is Emil Jones, who is the state's Majority Leader.
He's retiring.
He is Barack Obama's mentor.
He's African-American, 73 years old.
He may be a caretaker for the seat, but he's a possibility as well.
But anyway, that'll stay Democratic.
Same in Delaware.
Ruth Ann Minner is the Democratic governor there.
She's (unintelligible) of retiring, but she will name a Democrat to replace Joe Biden.
Biden is one of - you know, he obviously was up on the - he was reelected to his seventh term yesterday and obviously, he will step down.
That's what happened to Lyndon Johnson in 1960 - elected vice president and senator at the same time, stepping down from the Senate seat.
And it was thought that Joe Biden's son might be there to replace him.
Right.
Bo Biden who was the state attorney general, but he's with the Army National Guard in Iraq.

He doesn't come back until next October and there's a possibility that either Minner will name a caretaker person or perhaps even somebody else like the lieutenant governor - the outgoing lieutenant governor, who would like to have the seat and of course, would not want to give it up.
He would not want to be a caretaker.
He'd like to hold it on beyond 2010 when Bo Biden hopefully returns from Iraq.
And here's an email question to Andy Kohut.
Forget the circular firing squad among Republicans.
Now is the time for pollsters and analysts to take a look and figure out who got the statistics game right.
After thousands of surveys, dozens of methodological arguments and a pile of actually, you know, votes to look at, one thing seems clear, most of the pollsters have the election mostly right.
That doesn't mean that some of the principal controversies in polling sampling of cell phone users, for example, have been sorted out.
That, from Seth Coulter(ph).
Well, that's correct.
I mean, the polls did a reasonably good job.
This time, they did the same good job they did four years ago and eight years with close elections.
The national polls have a good track record and pretty good methodology for dealing with presidential elections.
Primaries are another thing.
But certainly, presidential elections turnout and many of the factors that we struggle with in this question - in this contest or race, the record speaks for itself.
It was pretty good.
Ken.
I think one thing we hopefully will bury forever is that the term Bradley effect.
We heard that over and over again.
Voters are saying they would vote for an African-American.
When they get in to the privacy voting booth, they don't do that.
But we've seen that basically, the polling was pretty true to form.
I think Obama was favored by seven points.
He won by maybe five, and the Bradley effect was perhaps an aberration of 1982 and nothing to talk about in the current stage of polling.
And it reflects the facts that race is less of an issue for the overwhelming majority of voters.
Especially among the young, right?
Among the young.
We did see about eight percent of the white votes saying they were considering race when they cast the ballot and they voted very heavily for John McCain 36 to 63 percent.
But they were eight percent of the vote and they were mostly older, mostly white southerners.
We'll get some more callers on the line.
And let's go to Chuck.
Chuck, calling us from San Francisco on the Democratic line.
Thank you very much and hi, everybody.
Hi, Chuck.
But I'm worried about another effect and that's the Carter effect and that the people that really run this country are going to marginalize President-Elect Obama.
And who are the people who really run the country?
Well, the people that really run that money and, you know, I think President Carter had a lot of good ideas but was not allowed to really carry them out.

And continuing to talk about beautiful pictures, maybe some of these pictures will show up from NASA in Braille edition or in ""Invisible Sky"" or some other way for people to see in all different forms.
I'm kind of wondering if maybe what we're seeing here is a trend towards what's been called a post partisan sort of situation where some of the old categories and clichés really don't hold up.

Specifically, what I mean is I was pretty surprised about the McCain campaign, the reliance on some fairly predictable sort of old clichés about how his opponent was a socialist and he was going to raise your taxes and he was weak on defense and you know, his patriotism was questionable and his religion was questionable and all these things - and I don't think the country has become unpatriotic or decided, you know, they want to be socialistic or anything.
But I'm wondering if now, we're entering an era where the analysis is a little bit more nuance and the discussion is a little bit - there's little bit more information entering into the discussion.
And that could be a consequence in part at least to the fact that communication technology has advanced to the point where the old kind of clichés just aren't effective anymore.
Thirty-second ads aren't the only way to communicate.
Andy Kohut, what do you think?
There's some evidence that these things really didn't work this time.
More religious voters - Obama was accused of being godless and religious less or secular.
And religious voters voted more Democratic than they did four years ago by a significant margin.
And one of the really interesting sidelights of this election was that while Obama was - clearly said - there was this question about raising taxes.
He carried by a 52 to 47 percent margin the $100,000 a year vote category.
And I think one of my colleagues told me that the $200,000 a year category, which is very small, he also carried that and he talked about raising taxes among people with $200,000 a year.
It's not - there are a lot of things that suggest the themes that were used just didn't fly.
Ken?

I suspect that one of the reasons that peripheral issues like the patriotism and socialism arguments didn't work is because of the overwhelming concern about the future, the economy and everybody's personal finances.
That, plus the war in Iraq, I suspect, that drowned out the other issues that might have played in a different kind of election's atmosphere.

And to be fair, given the money disadvantage or the money advantage, depending on how you look at it, Republicans were stuck running pretty much negative advertising for the most part while the Democrats could afford to run some negative ads and a lot of positive ads as well so that they would appeal to voters on both sides.

And look where the battleground states, where they were all red states that President Bush won, Barack Obama carried every state that John Kerry won in 2004 including Pennsylvania by a comfortable margin.
Chuck, thanks for the call.
Can I just ask, would you guys agree that this election, not only because of its duration but other reasons actually, had a little bit more content to it?
You know, actual information, detailed debate and discussion.
On the issues?
On the issues.
What do you think, Andy?
I'm going to pass on that one.
I don't know how to answer that.
Ken?
I'd like to get a lifeline.
(Soundbite of laughter)
